Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Mild nausea, occasional dizziness. Symptoms appear to cycle every 48 hours.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Visited a local clinic on the second day of symptoms; given antipyretics which temporarily lowered the fever but did not resolve other symptoms.

Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Sepsis, typhoid fever, leptospirosis, hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome, schistosomiasis, biliary tract infection, and urinary tract infection. Ruling out these based on travel history, symptom pattern, and blood smear results.

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient with malaria diagnosis based on clinical presentation and positive blood smear. Initiating antimalarial therapy (Artemisinin-based combination therapy). Monitor vitals, CBC, renal function, and blood glucose levels.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1: Fever reduced to 37.5°C, headache and limb aches persist. Day 2: Fever spikes again to 38.5°C, reoccurring symptoms. Adjusting antibiotic therapy.

Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: End of Week 1: Patient responding to antimalarial treatment, fevers less frequent and severe. Monitoring for complications.

Parasitic Diseases.Name: Malaria
Parasitic Diseases.Symptoms: The main symptoms of malaria are chills, high fever, sweating, headache, limb aches, and fatigue. After a certain incubation period, the symptoms recur. Severe cases can lead to complications such as anemia, hypoglycemia, acute renal failure, or acute pulmonary edema.
Parasitic Diseases.Differential Diagnosis: Malaria should be differentiated from various febrile diseases such as sepsis, typhoid, leptospirosis, hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome, schistosomiasis, biliary tract infections, and urinary tract infections. When it develops into cerebral malaria, it should be differentiated from Japanese encephalitis, moderate bacillary dysentery, sporadic viral encephalitis, etc.

Parasitic Diseases:
Name: Malaria
Symptoms: The main symptoms of malaria are chills, high fever, sweating, headache, limb aches, and fatigue. After a certain incubation period, the symptoms recur. Severe cases can lead to complications such as anemia, hypoglycemia, acute renal failure, or acute pulmonary edema.
Differential Diagnosis: Malaria should be differentiated from various febrile diseases such as sepsis, typhoid, leptospirosis, hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome, schistosomiasis, biliary tract infections, and urinary tract infections. When it develops into cerebral malaria, it should be differentiated from Japanese encephalitis, moderate bacillary dysentery, sporadic viral encephalitis, etc.

qa_summary.question: According to the hospitalization records of Ashland General Hospital, summarize the present illness of L. Brown.
qa_summary.answer: L. Brown's symptoms began 3 days ago after returning from a trip to Nigeria. He has a high fever (up to 39°C), severe chills, intense headache, sweating, limb aches, and fatigue. Symptoms are severe and interfere with daily activities. Accompanying symptoms include mild nausea and occasional dizziness, with symptoms cycling every 48 hours. He visited a local clinic on the second day of symptoms and was given antipyretics, which temporarily lowered the fever but did not resolve other symptoms. His appetite is slightly reduced, urination and defecation are normal, weight is stable, and sleep is disturbed due to fever and chills.
